results.title: Dots and dashes
results.creator_credit: Jacob Romeril, Kevin Coughlin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Catching mumps just before his 18th birthday prevented Kevin Coughlin from joining the RAAF during the second World War. But thanks to his connections, he was able to get work as a Wireless Telegraphist. In the end, Kevin ended up with skills that made him unique. Naturally left handed, he was forced to tap out morse code with his right hand. This afforded him a dexterity that meant he could do morse code with his right hand and write with his left which made him invaluable. He tells of his time in Darwin and, later, on Peron Island in the Timor Sea.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jacob Romeril, Kevin Coughlin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [September 2009]
results.brief_description: 10 interviews with Victorian war veterans, created as part of the “In our words : Stories from Victorian veterans” Digital Storytelling workshop in August 2009, with the support of the Department of Planning and Community Development, the Shrine of Remembrance, and the Victorian Veterans Council.

results.title: An Interview with Stan Guilfoyle
results.brief_description: When he was 13, Stan Guilfoyle was in an accident in which he nearly died. From then on he believed in seizing every moment. This enthusiasm for life took him to the Royal Australian Air Force, where he became proficient at flying, using only the instruments in his cockpit to navigate. He tells of his time in Indonesia during World War II and passionately shares his views on war.

results.title: An Interview with Shirley Cornish
results.brief_description: Shirley Cornish joined the army when a friend, from the store where she worked, said she would. She joined the Australian Womens Army Service and spent most of her life in the service of the army, and tells of her times there and friends made. Army life often bled into Shirley’s personal life, losing a rank in order to spend more time with her mother and, later, joining the Bentleigh War Widows and Widowed Mothers after her husband died. Shirley considers joining this association to be the best thing she ever did and even went on to become its president.

production_dates.notes: Workshop was in August 2009 but project completed in September 2009

results.title: An Interview with Raymond Jungwirth
results.brief_description: Raymond Jungwirth wanted to fly a spitfire but was convinced to undergo observer training. Initially trained in Canada, Raymond was posted to Europe, where he spent most of World War II. Here he provides a heartfelt account of friends made and lost, the waste of human life and visiting Belsen after the war and the lasting impression that stayed with him even after he returned to Australia.

results.title: An Interview with Jessie Perkins
results.brief_description: Jessie Perkins was 16 when World War II started. When she was 18, Japan entered the war and Jessie was keen to contribute, but her dad wouldn’t let her. She tells of how her convinced her father to let her go, her time at the Australian Army Service Corp in Geelong and, ultimately, her long and distinguished career in the army.

results.title: An Interview with Brigadier Keith Rossi
results.brief_description: Brigadier Keith Rossi went to join up but needed to lie about his age to do so. He tells of his time in the army with humour, capturing the cameraderie that helped alleviate the horror of war. In his time serving, he went from the Middle East, to New Guinea and, later, Vietnam, from Private to Brigadier.

results.title: An Interview with Billie Lindsay
results.brief_description: Billie had just gone through training as a nurse when she was whisked away to war. She tells how she was immediately signed up while waiting for a friend, her time in Malaya and considers the way we look at war today and how her time in the army stood her in good stead later on in life.
results.description: Billie had just gone through training as a nurse when she was whisked away to war. results.title: An Interview with Alf Argent
results.brief_description: When Alf finished school, World War II had started. He signed up but was not called up for service until after he graduated from Duntroon at age 18. Alf then tells the story of his journey, through the Korean War, the Vietnam War to training in Europe and how he got to see the effects of war first-hand. A distinguised man who led an extraordinary life.

results.title: Mountains of memories : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description: Four stories from people with a deep connection to the Victorian Alpine Country. From different backgrounds, they share their experiences of working, living and travelling to the Alpine country, the stories of ancestors who have mined and lived in the region and how the Alpine country has left an indeliable impression on their lives.
